title: England star Jonathan Joseph hails childhood friend Tyrone Mings for his handling of racist abuse
text:
England centre Jonathan Joseph has paid tribute to his friend, Tyrone Mings, for the way he responded to being racially abused on his England football debut in Sofia.

The 26-year-old Aston Villa defender and several black team-mates were subjected to disgraceful chants from sections of the crowd, before and during a European Championship qualifier against Bulgaria, which England eventually won 6-0.

The loud and sustained abuse led to two stoppages in the game and left the visitors weighing up whether to walk off.

Jonathan Joseph has come out in support of Tyrone Mings after he was racially abused

Mings was making his debut for England in Bulgaria when he was one of the players targeted

Having caught up on the events, which took place overnight here in Japan, Joseph was asked if he had spoken to his friend Mings.

'No I haven't. He is probably asleep right now,' said Joseph.

'I have seen bits of it, read up on it. It's not great what happened out in Bulgaria.

'From what I have heard, they were very professional about it and at the same time trying to stand up for what is right as well.

'We are fortunate in the sport we are in to not to see any of that stuff happen to us. You just hope things will get better for them.'

Joseph also put aside the controversy of the occasion to add: 'On a personal level, I am delighted that he has got his first cap. It could have been in better circumstances, but I'm happy to see a mate do so well.'

Joseph and Mings are friends from their days at Millfield School in Somerset.

Mings gets a congratulatory hug from England manager Gareth Southgate after the game

Joseph, in Japan for the Rugby World Cup, is a childhood friend of Mings from Millfield School
